1082675324041773061.text: This allows users to choose which curation rules they want, while also allowing them to seamlessly move between curators/interfaces. It's actually pretty cool.

1082675321743106049.text: With blockchain-based social media, companies compete on UX and curation. You'll notice http://Busy.org  is a much better interface than Steemit, has better functionality, and also has different rules around which content it shows.

1082675320120053760.text: In existing social media (ex. Twitter), a ban is a ban. Users who are banned from Twitter lose their data and their audience and have to move elsewhere. Twitter has obviously gotten heat for their policies around this.

1082675318878584832.text: If you have a Steem account that you access through http://Steemit.com , you can log into http://Busy.org  with your same account. All your data is there. And in this case, you can view content that other interfaces have either banned or simply excluded.

1082675317578350592.text: Other interfaces exist, and users can easily port between them; all of their data is maintained bc these interfaces use the same back end: the Steem blockchain.

1050380117384531968.text: I do agree with James on some things. Namely that the current constitution has problems and needs to be changed, specifically with regards to arbitration. Constructive criticism is important and welcome. Blatant misinformation is not.

1050380116398878722.text: they would destroy the value of the network that's paying them. They also run the risk of being voted out by token holders and losing their future income and reputation (since BPs are publicly known companies and individuals). And there are plenty of standby BPs ready to step in.

1050380115123851269.text: James asserts (again without evidence) that cartels control block production on EOS. Concentration of power is largely unavoidable (see PoW mining), but systems can be implemented that put checks in place. BPs are not incentivized to act maliciously, since..

1050380113806811137.text: This is not a problem unique to EOS or even to the dApp world. Remember that EOS dApps also have the option of requiring users to bring their own account and bandwidth, rather than providing it for them.

1050380112082980864.text: This tweet is a convoluted way of saying that dApps will need to create business models if they want to recoup their development costs or be profitable. There are dApps like @EOSBetCasino that have already shown this to be possible.https://twitter.com/JamesSpediacci/status/1049811641934565376 …

1050380111067979778.text: James takes issue with how EOS distributes block rewards. EOS currently has 1% inflation (much less than most networks of its size, plus no tx fees!), and EOS holders will likely be able to beat inflation by renting out their excess bandwidth using @ChintaiEOS or the upcoming REX

1050380109927116800.text: Further, EOS BPs have actual operating costs and have to sell much of their earned EOS to cover these costs. The infrastructure requirements of EOS BPs are much higher than typical PoS systems.

1050380108698198016.text: DPOS is not a rich get richer system, since your stake determines your voting power, not your block producing power (and thus your share of block rewards, like pure PoS). BPs aren't the richest ones in the ecosystem, they're the ones with the most votes.

1050380106953297920.text:
"An EOS BP is just a corporate-owned server." 

....just like PoW miners and many future PoS validating servers. This is a nonsense argument. When there's money to be made, professional organizations step in. That's not a bad thing.

1050380105690861568.text: James claims that Blockone is using its stake to influence the list of BPs. While B1 has every right to participate in voting as a token holder, they are not currently doing so. James could easily verify that by looking at any EOS block explorer:https://bloks.io/account/b1

1050380104394858496.text: Just because transactions are free (one of EOS's best features) doesn't automatically mean that dApp activity is fake. That's a bold assertion made with no evidence. Further, DAU counts are based on accounts interacting with the dApp. As James noted, accounts are not free.

1050380103035875328.text: James says that account creation costs $17. Today, to create an account on EOS costs ~$1.70, and that cost has been steadily going down thanks to increased RAM supply and optimizations to account creation. Some wallets offer acct creation for cheaper or even for free.

1050380101823713282.text: To start, Dan didn't "throw out" the constitution, since he has no power to do that. He just proposed a new version that may or may not be adopted by the community. That's what you do when you encounter a problem-- propose a solution.

1050380100594745344.text: Sensationalism sells, but truth is more important. Let's look at the reality behind some of these claims.

1021103862843887616.text: Yes, this model does not capture value in the same way that a global digital monetary standard does (likely $10T+), but that doesn't mean it's not interesting or useful!

1021103860868317190.text: Token holders can actively influence the direction of the platform to change and improve the services and experience it offers. Their influence is proportional to their stake. Equity-like, but also not traditional equity. Still trying to find the best term to describe this setup.

1021103859547205633.text: With EOS, its more like a decentralized firm where users can opt-in based on whether or not the network provides good services at a good price (services being decentralized computation).

1021103858339205122.text: This model _does not_ make sense for sound money. For a global monetary standard, those with more ownership shouldn’t have the most influence. That’s why Bitcoin’s p2p governance model makes sense. People have to participate in money, so plutocracy is bad.

1021103856619573248.text: This model lines up certain incentives well. Those who most need the resources are those with the most wealth stored (and thus the most at stake). They have the most say in the evolution of the platform. As they should!

1021103854883164160.text: Users and apps/dApps should hold the tokens based on their individual resource needs. In doing so, they are storing wealth in the token for the duration that they need that access.

1021103853721325569.text: EOS token ownership is a pro-rata claim on network resources, in perpetuity. Not money, not equity. Similar to both in terms of how it is used within the protocol, but objectively different. Tokens are valuable because these resources are scare and in demand.

1021103852316225536.text: Decentralized computation platforms are a set of scare resources. How do you allocate them? In EOS these resources are computation, bandwidth, RAM, storage, and voting power (for validators and for changes to the protocol).

1021103850483257346.text:
EOS is the only token model that incentivizes holding while being neither equity nor money (but retaining certain useful properties of each). 

Don’t @ me even if it’s the last thing you ever do.
